title: Bank of England policymaker: We probably won't forecast the next crisis â as it happened | Business | The Guardian
summary: european markets higher but ftse 100 slips back .
greek government claims success after eurogroup meeting .
us service and manufacturing figures below expectations .
carney : we know the world is changing .
carney : we 're a little concerned about consumer borrowing .
haldane quizzed on how qe helped the richest .

documents.title: european markets higher but ftse 100 slips back
text: better than expected eurozone growth figures and a strong start on wall street with yet more new peaks have combined to push european markets higher , despite continuing political worries ahead of the french presidential election .
but badly received results from hsbc have left the ftse 100 lagging its peers .

the final scores showed : the ftse 100 finished down 0.34 % or 25.03 points at 7274.83 , with hsbc itself knocking nearly 37 points off the leading index germany 's dax rose 1.18 % to 11,967.49 france 's cac closed up 0.49 % at 4888.76 italy 's ftse mib was 0.34 % better at 19,043.58 spain 's ibex ended 0.36 % higher at 9561.0 in greece , the athens market added 1.43 % to 655.20 on wall street , the dow jones industrial average is currently up 90 points or 0.44 % at 20,714 having earlier hit a record 20,757 .
on that note , it is time to close for the evening .
thanks for all your comments , and we 'll be back tomorrow .

over in greece workers with the communist-aligned labour group , pame have taken to the streets to protest the prospect of yet more austerity measures , our correspondent helena smith reports : thousands of protestors are marching en masse towards parliament in syntagma square chanting : we are not going to be spectators of our own wretchedness .

the demonstration is one of 40 taking place across greece in protest over the government 's decision to agree to further talks with creditors in return for up front legislation of more unpopular cost-cutting measures .

addressing the crowd , the communist kke party leader dimitris koutsoumbas said : while the government is writing , directing and playing in this new episode of deceit against the greek people that has been played a thousand times before , we are here , in the struggle with the working class and the rest of the peoples ' movement , loudly shouting it can not go on !
our people can not endure new measures against their income , against their and their childrens ' lives .
here lies hope , in the fight , in the struggle , together with the kke , for a better way to be able to be found for us , for our children .
for all of the greek people .
members of the pame trade union protesting in athens konstantinidis/reuters protestors are demanding an end to austerity measures .
konstantinidis/reuters protests follow monday 's eurogroup meeting .
konstantinidis/reuters
with far-right french presidential candidate marine le pen gaining ground according to opinion polls , the euro has come under further pressure .

jasper lawler , senior market analyst at london capital group , said : in a sign of relative weakness , the euro fell against most major currencies despite the upbeat data [ showing eurozone growth at a near six year high ] .
political risk is clearly trumping economic strength in the currency market .
the pound is currently up 0.6 % against the euro at ¬1.1817 having climbed as high at ¬1.1839 .

documents.title: greek government claims success after eurogroup meeting
text: the greek government has claimed a decisive victory following monday 's eurogroup announcement that a common understanding had been reached between creditors and athens .

helena smith reports : amid accusations of crossing its own red lines ' , prime minister alexis tsipras ' leftist-led coalition went on the offensive today calling monday 's euro group a huge success that had ultimately put greece on the path to economic recovery .
the position of the greek government for not a euro more of austerity has been respected and accepted by all , the government spokesman dimitris tzanakopoulos told reporters .

the demand for ¬4.5bn worth of extra measures in 2019 is no longer on the agenda of discussion , he said adding that upfront legislation of reforms that would be enforced as of january 2019 would be offset by counter measures and so fiscally neutral .
echoing that view senior government figures said counter measures would henceforth be voted through parliament alongside further cuts .
there is no room for further austerity , the minister of digital policy nikos pappas told ant1 tv .

measures and counter-measures will be voted together after the review has been completed , he insisted , explaining that if the tax-free threshold was reduced to ¬6,000 , as the imf has long demanded , other measures would be taken to reduce the negative impact on vulnerable groups .
greek finance minister euclid tsakalotos , left , witheu commissioner pierre moscovici at monday 's eurogroup meeting .
monasse/ap but seven years into the crisis there was widespread cynicism that the vaunted change of policy mix , also announced at the eurogroup , would work .
across the board , political opponents accused the government of engaging in window-dressing and double speak .
the so-called agreement did little more than prolong negotiations over the review , the former finance minister evangelos venizelos claimed .

no decision had been taken as to what would happen when the current bailout programme expires in 2018 , or how creditors would deal with the country 's staggering debt pile or even when greece would enter the ecb 's qe programme , he said .
the negotiation will be prolonged for a few more months in expectation , presumably , of the next german government , said venizelos .
in other words what was agreed was the extension of the negotiation until dramatic dilemmas appear , he added referring to the huge debt repayments greece faces in july .
back in the uk , and here 's our story on the treasury select committee .

phillip inman writes : the bank of england is unlikely to predict the next financial crisis , according to one of the central bank 's leading policymakers , who said economic models were unable to provide flawless forecasts for the uk economy .

monetary policy committee member , gertjan vlieghe , said it was impossible for the bank to forecast a recession , let alone the next crash and no amount of fine-tuning models of the way the modern economy operates would change that harsh reality .
appearing before mps , vlieghe warned it was inevitable there would be forecasting errors , which could include missing a cataclysmic event such as the 2008 banking crisis .
he said : we are probably not going to forecast the next financial crisis , or forecast the next recession .
our models are just not that good .

the bank should continue trying to improve and refine its forecasting models , he said , but it was misguided for mps to demand that economic forecasts offer a high degree of certainty about events that could happen several years from now .
vlieghe , a former city economist , was answering criticisms from mps on the treasury select committee over a series of forecasting errors in the run-up to the brexit vote .
the full story is here : we will not spot the next financial crisis , predicts bank of england read more
the disappointing us data could dim some of the expectations of a forthcoming interest rate rise , analysts believe .

dennis de jong , managing director at ufx.com , said : president donald trump has n't had much reason to be concerned about the financial markets since arriving at the white house , but today 's reports of a slowing in manufacturing growth could give the president a momentary headache .

after figures went into overdrive after his election victory in november , trump was keen to paint himself as the reason for the resurgence in american factory production but this is a setback he wo n't be able to blame on another administration .
fed chair janet yellen has already hinted at further interest rate hikes during 2017 , but with uncertainty on the horizon , that may end up being later rather than sooner .
paul sirani , chief market analyst at xtrade , said : the us manufacturing sector continues to operate at positive levels , although february 's figure may be viewed as a small backwards step .
factories have been riding the crest of a wave since november 's election , but today 's drop could be a sign of things to come .
exports are likely to drop right off as a result of high inflation and uncertainty surrounding donald trump 's trade policy , and that will hit manufacturing hard .
until all aspects of the us economy are heading in the right direction , fed chair janet yellen is expected to hold fire on raising interest rates .

the post-us election optimism could be running out of steam , says chris williamson , chief business economist at ihs markit : the drop in the flash pmi numbers for february suggest that the post-election upturn has lost some momentum .
growth of business output , new orders and hiring all waned , as did inflationary pressures .
february also saw a sharp pull-back in business optimism about the outlook over the next 12 months , which suggests companies have become more cautious about spending , investing and hiring .
however , even with the february dip , the pmi remains at a level broadly consistent with the economy growing at a 2.5 % annualized rate in the first quarter .
the survey 's employment index is meanwhile indicating that a respectable 165,000 jobs were added to the economy in february .
manufacturing output markit

documents.title: us service and manufacturing figures below expectations
text: the us service and manufacturing sectors have grown by less than expected so far in february , according to new figures .
the initial markit service sector pmi for the month came in at 53.9 , compared to 55.6 in january and expectations of a figure of 55.8 .
markit 's preliminary manufacturing pmi for february was 54.3 , down from 55 in january and lower than the forecast rise to 55.3 .
the composite index fell from 55.8 in january to 54.3 .
sigma squawk ( @ sigmasquawk ) us pmi comes in below expectations.services 53.9 vs exp 55.6 , manufacturing 54.3 vs exp 55.0

documents.title: us markets hit new peaks
text: over in the us , and stock markets have opened at record highs after monday 's holiday , lifted by positive reaction to results from retailers wal-mart and home depot , a rise in the oil price and a stronger dollar .
the dow jones industrial average climbed to 20,688 , up 64 points while the s & p 500 opened up 0.23 % and the nasdaq composite 0.17 % .
oil prices have been boosted by comments from opec that it was hopeful that members would comply with the deal to cut production .
west texas intermediate is currently up 1.13 % at $ 54.53 a barrel .
the dollar is also higher after recent comments from federal reserve officials hinting at forthcoming interest rate rises .
over in europe the was more mixed .
germany 's dax is up 0.7 % with france 's cac up 0.39 % .
but the ftse 100 has fallen 0.8 % or 6 % , with hsbc alone knocking 33 points off the index following its worse than expected results .

the session looked like a win for mps not the mpc , reckons ranko berich , head of market analysis at monex europe : today , for once , the monetary policy committee did not give as good as it got from the treasury select committee .

long-time carney baiters such as steve baker made some very good points about the boe 's lack of clarity in forward guidance and its recent patchy forecast history , yet ultimately we learned little about how the outlook for monetary policy has changed in recent months .
this is mainly because inflation prospects are still surrounded by extraordinary amounts of uncertainty .
much of the boe 's willingness to look through the coming surge in inflation seems to rest on stability in long term expectations .
but inflation expectations are rising , and with consumers on the verge of digesting more price increases , the boe 's commitment to look through inflation could become increasingly limited .
as ian mccafferty said , we 're about to learn a lot more about how the costs of sterling 's depreciation will be split between firms and consumers .
how investment intentions and consumer spending change as a result of this adjustment could end up either completely upending the boe 's forecasts ( again ) or proving them right all along .
with this much uncertainty , it 's no wonder carney stayed well clear of providing even vague guidance on the future direction of rates .

here 's some reaction to the bank of england hearing , from committee member helen goodman mp : helen goodman ( @ helengoodmanmp ) interesting session with # carney of # bankofengland : forecast assumes immigration falls from 300k to 150k .
helen goodman ( @ helengoodmanmp ) but unfortunately # bankofengland still not prepared to ask hard questions on their own role in creating house price rises .
helen goodman ( @ helengoodmanmp ) bank says pressures on employers and employees post # brexit mean more conflict and aggro to be expected in wage negotiations .
and finally , mark carney warns against reading too much into the ftse 100 's rally since last summer , to record highs .
the governor points out that the blue-chip index is packed with international firms who earn dollars overseas ( which are now worth more in sterling terms ) .
a better guide to britain 's economic health is the yield on 10-year uk debt , which has gone sideways ' since the brexit vote .
that suggests that bond vigilante are cautious about longer-term growth prospects .
and that 's the end of a rather bruising session with the treasury committee .
steve baker mp ( another non-fan of mark carney ) has been cheekily checking his phone during the session .

he admits that he 's been following the highly amusing ' commentary from twitter user @ twitterid yoda ( @ jedieconomist ) ugh ugh ugh i 'm not sure the boe will be as amused yoda ( @ jedieconomist ) boe vlieghe `` there are not one model that is wrong , and this one is right '' no , wrong they always are , and cut rates they always will .

yoda ( @ jedieconomist ) q : did the boe feed the housing bubblehaldane : ok this depends on how you cut the cake but qe has benefited everybody. # sociopath yoda ( @ jedieconomist ) talking about the phillips curve , mccafferty is , ugh ugh ugh.making this up they are , yessss keep you eyes on the witnesses , mr baker
in a determined effort to get himself dis-invited from this year 's bank of england christmas party , kit malthouse mp has asked mark carney about forward guidance !

[ this was carney 's great innovation when he joined the bank ; a promise that interest rates would n't rise until the unemployment rate fell to 7 % , it was then fudged once the rate fell sharply below that level ] malthouse asks if the current forward guidance is that interest rates will rise twice over the forecast horizon , as the quarterly inflation report shows .
carney : the forecast is determined by the market curve at the time of the forecast - the financial markets expected two rate rises , so there it is .
so what 's your forward guidance now ?
is it that rates are going to go up , down , or is it neutral ?
carney refuses to elaborate , arguing it would be wrong to go further than the mpc 's own pronouncements .
he looks irked that forward guidance was even brought up .

live alberto gallo ( @ macrocredit ) carney : rates may rise faster or slower than market expects # rosesareredvioletsareblue zerohedge ( @ zerohedge ) and now some value added boe forecasts : carney : rates may rise faster or slower than market expects
on food inflation , carney says consumers should expect fresh food prices to rise to counter the fall in the pound , which makes imports more expensive .
packaged goods producers have more leeway ' to absorb the impact of sterling 's depreciation , as they can look to save costs elsewhere .

documents.title: carney : we know the world is changing
text: conservative mp kit malthouse manages to rile mark carney by asking if the bank of england is still locked into a pre-2008 mindset , and struggling to understand the modern world .
malthouse argues that we 're now in a sod it economy , where people are deciding to get on with their lives rather than waiting for conditions to improve .
carney gets into full rebuttal mode , says central banks have learned from what happened a decade ago , and adapted .
he led the bank of canada though the financial crisis , so will bridle ' at the assertion that policymakers do n't know what they 're doing .
he agrees , though , that the world has changed - the gig economy is changing the labour market , and the way wage bargaining works .
machine learning , and artificial intelligence , are making major changes to the way the economy runs .
we were derided when andy haldane talked about the robot revolution a year ago , carney says , but it 's hugely important .
the ageing population is another issue .
in that case , malthouse asks , why are n't you weaving more of this into your forecasts ?
especially as mr vlieghe says he does n't have confidence in them .

[ that 's not exactly what vlieghe meant , when he said the bank would n't spot the next crisis coming ] carney replies that the bank is conducting research into all these issues , and considering whether it makes more tangible ' forecasts about long-term risks .
the danger , though , is that these risks are seen as predictions
so , are the risks to household consumption more to the upside or the downside compared to the bank 's forecasts , reeves continues ?
just one word will do mpc member gertjan vlieghe wo n't be boxed into a single-word reply .
the risks are to both sides , he insists .
consumption data at the end of last year was strong , but it 's fallen off in the last few weeks .
carney and mcafferty agree that risks are to both sides .
haldane , though , plumps for downside .

documents.title: carney : we 're a little concerned about consumer borrowing
text: labour mp rachel reeves clips the edge of the bullseye , by asking whether the bank is worried about rising consumer borrowing .
mark carney concedes that the bank is a little concerned ' that lending criteria are being relaxed , to allow riskier lending .
we 're concerned enough to look at it more closely he cites the fact that consumers can now transfer a credit balance and get up to 40 months of interest-free credit .
the company taking on the loan can also bank some future earnings from this new customer straight away , carney explains .

documents.title: haldane quizzed on how qe helped the richest
text: labour mp helen goodman turns to the bank 's quantitative easing stimulus programme .

she says that bank analysis , released in 2012 , showed that the wealthiest 5 % of the population had received â£ 185,000 from qe , but this did n't get a lot of publicity until prime minister theresa may criticised the bank 's action last year .
she cites a speech that andy haldane gave last year in redcar , on the consequences and limits of monetary policy .
q : are you not a little bit concerned that the bank has fed the housing bubble ?

haldane says he has been trying to set out the distributional consequences of the financial crisis , and the way the burden has fallen differently across income levels , where people live , how old they are , and whether they own a house .
but he insists that qe has benefited every section of the population ( by supporting growth and employment ) .
and he disputes that the bank has distorted the housing market - house prices have been going up over a long time , due to a disparity between supply and demand .
q : but your own numbers show that the richest 5 % received â£ 185,000 each .
that 's enough to buy a house in my constituency [ goodman represents bishop auckland , county durham ] .
haldane agrees that â£ 185,000 is a significant amount , and that qe has pushed up house prices .
but he is adamant that qe has n't hurt the poor : have the effects been felt equally across the economy , across regions , across households , no , they have n't .
but does that mean that people been disadvantaged in absolute terms ?
there the evidence is very much to the contrary .
[ explainer : the bank has created â£ 425bn of new money through qe , to buys government bonds from commercial banks , so they can buy riskier assets ] .
the weakening in the pound may lead to more animated ' wage bargaining than we 've seen in the past , ian mccafferty adds .

q : it is highly likely that there will be less immigration over the next few years ; did you take this into account when you lowered your estimate of the equilibrium levels of unemployment to 4.5 % , from 5 % ?
ian mccafferty says that an expectation of lower immigration is already build into the bank 's forecasts .
but there are risks to that forecasts .
recent figures suggests immigration may fall faster than forecast .
alternatively , the uk may grow faster than other european countries , meaning we remain a magnet for immigration ' .
q : is n't it striking and bizarre that the bank of england have n't changed its economic assumptions since the government signalled the uk will leave the single market ?
haldane says that the bank feels this wo n't have a significant near term impact on its inflation and output projections over the forecast horizon , so no need to rip up the forecasting models yet .
q : when might uk interest rates start to rise ?
ian mccafferty says there is some hope that interest rates could start to normalise in two or three years
not for the first time , governor mark carney reminds the treasury committee that the bank took some significant decisions after the eu referendum that mitigated the impact of that vote .
and yet i think we just have to accept that we 're never going to get any credit for it .

documents.title: boe chief economist : i find risk hard to understand
text: live jacob rees-mogg suggests the bank should be more circumspect about its forecasts , rather than presenting them as holy writ , and then dismissing them six months later .
andy haldane replies , saying the bank does use fan charts to show the probability of the future path of growth and inflation .
but he concedes that it 's hard to convey this sense of uncertainty to the wider world .
the bank 's chief economist says : we know that people find risk hard to understand , i find risk hard to understand .
[ this may explain why haldane is prepared to compare the bank 's forecasting to dodgy weather forecasting - not , perhaps , a career-enhancing move ]
now jacob rees-mogg , conservative mp and persistent thorn in the bank of england 's side , takes over the questioning .
he congratulates andy haldane on his extraordinarily interesting speech and interview last month ( on michael fish forecasting errors ) .
but he 's concerned that haldane thinks that the bank would have taken the same monetary policy decisions , even if it had better forecasting .
haldane says there are places where the bank is doing its best to learn lessons and improve its models to reflect changes in the economy .
but , as vleighe explained earlier , that ca n't prevent the occasional making of errors , not all of which are mistakes .

conservative mp chris phelp makes the bank of england look a little silly q : your chart on page 31 of the quarterly inflation report shows that long-term inflation expectations are around 3 % , so does n't that mean that the financial markets do n't believe price rises are transitory ?
carney tries to swat this away .
these graphs measures the retail prices index , not the consumer prices index - and rpi is usually 1 % higher than cpi , he says smoothly .
that 's not clear in the report , phelp shoots back .
he squints at his report and spots that it says cpi ' inflation in the subheading .
see of england dr gertjan vlieghe tries to help , saying that some of the surveys of inflation expectation specify beween cpi and rpi , and others do n't .
so is this chart measuring cpi , rpi , or a fudge , asks phelp triumphantly .
haldane thinks the survey does n't specify .
fudge it is , then !
onto inflation , which is poised to jump over the bank 's target of 2 % .
ian mccafferty says we are getting close ' to the limit of how much inflation overshoot can be tolerated .
carney sounds less concerned , saying the overshoot is entirely ' down to the currency factor , so the bank must watch out for signs that inflation is pushing wages up .

the bank policymakers may be losing patience with the committee carney points out that they 've spend an hour fielding questions about forecasting the past , and not touched on the issues facing the economy in the future .
tyrie agrees that the session is running behind schedule , and suggests that the boe provide shorter answers !
john mann mp is n't impressed pointing out that the bank of england has n't changed its forecasting to address the massive changes in house ownership in the uk .
q : are n't you behind the times when it comes to assessing consumer behaviour ?
governor mark carney defends the bank 's forecasts after the brexit vote - saying they were less pessimistic than other forecasters , just not optimistic enough .

he agrees there has been a big structural change in uk home ownership , and millennial attitudes to home ownership and rent [ attitude is a funny word to use - someone 's attitude to buying a house is somewhat irrelevant if they simply ca n't afford one ]
chief economist andy haldane now hits back against the mps ' criticism .
he says that his michael fish speech last month was meant to highlight that the forecast errors around the brexit vote are much smaller than before the financial crisis in 2008 .
ian mccafferty is also stung by the committee 's earlier criticism - the boe is revising its models to try to improve its forecasting record , he points out robustly .
andy bruce ( @ brucereuters ) bank of england 's vlieghe : probably not going to forecast the next financial crisis or recession .
the models just are n't that good .
john ashmore ( @ smashmoreph ) `` i 'm never confident of any forecast '' says bank of england economist gertjan vlieghe .
silvia borrelli ( @ london silvia ) mpc member vlieghe dismisses idea that @ twitterid would deliver better forecasts if it improved its models : its a probabilistic exercise

documents.title: boe 's vlieghe : we probably wo n't forecast the next crisis
text: dr gertjan vleighe live another mpc member , dr gertjan vlieghe , criticises the idea that the bank would deliver flawless forecasts for the uk economy if it could only improve its models .
he tells the treasury committee that however good the models are , it is inevitable that there will be forecasting errors .
forecasts are , after all , only a measure of the probability of something happening .
as vlieghe puts it : we are probably not going to forecast the next financial crisis , or forecast the next recession .
our models are just not that good .
of course , the bank should keep trying to improve and refine its forecasting models , vlieghe continues but it 's simply wrong to think we will ever get certainty .

mpc member ian mccafferty argues that surveys of business activity are usually very helpful ; but at times of major economic or political shock , they can give a misleading for example , after the brexit vote , surveys showed a very large fall in corporate and consumer confidence - but things quickly returned to equilibrium , faster than you might expect .

documents.title: haldane : consumers have looked through political uncertainty
text: the bank of england is now challenged over its decision to raise its growth forecasts this year from 1.4 % to 2 % q : would the bank have done a better job of forecasting the uk economy if it had thought that voting for brexit might be a good thing , not a bad one ?

andy haldane says there are several reasons why the bank raised its growth forecasts , including the fiscal loosening in the autumn statement , a recovering global growth , and somewhat stronger consumer spending .
a majority of consumers have looked through what we 've seen in the last six to nine months .
maybe that should n't be a surprise , haldane concedes , as they 're still in employment .
they 're spending what is coming in .
but people are going to face a squeeze in the months ahead as inflation rises .

livesquawk ( @ livesquawk ) boe 's haldane : autumn budget statement will have a material effect on uk economic growth shaun richards ( @ notayesmansecon ) andrew tyrie really skewered andy haldane on this subject as he waffled and contradicted himself # boe # tsc
back in december , mark carney generously invited the whole committee to the bank 's christmas party .

but there 's no festive spirit this morning : will martin ( @ willmartin19 ) carney and tyrie 's clear disdain for one another is great to watch ben glaze ( @ benglaze ) quite testy exchanges between tyrie and mark carney at treasury select committee .
they seem to like winding each other up
tyrie then asks haldane to justify the bank 's confidence that the â£ 23bn productivity spending announced in last year 's autumn statement will boost uk growth .
surely this is quite a small stimulus ?
haldane says this fiscal loosening will help , but there is still a net headwind ' from budget cuts in future years .
when did the bank last change its estimate of the equilibrium level of unemployment [ before this month ] , chairman tyrie asks .
ian mccafferty does n't know .
nor does chief economist andy haldane .

so governor mark carney rides to the team 's rescue , with a long answer about how the bank now holds comprehensive annual reviews of its economic measures tyrie 's heard enough - and wants the boe to come back to him and say exactly when it was last changed , and whether it was ever voted on .
he points out that , by cutting this rate from 5 % to 4.5 % , the bank has given itself the green light to forecast higher growth without worrying about inflationary consequences .
carney comes back , saying the boe has been over-estimating wage growth for some time , suggesting there is more slack in the labour market than thought .
so it is right to examine its assumptions about the economy .
you can watch the treasury committee hearing here .
next question goes to ian mccafferty - does he support the bank 's decision to reduce the equilibrium level ' of uk unemployment from 5 % to 4.5 % ?
[ this measures how close britain is to full employment ] .
mccafferty says he accepted the move , but would have favoured a smaller move to just 4.75 % .
he argues that britain is actually closer to full employment than current weak wage growth suggests .
bank of england policymakers at the treasury committee live

documents.title: mps grill the bank of england
text: over at parliament , the treasury committee is starting its session with bank of england governor mark carney and senior colleagues .

chief economist andy haldane take the new ball , with a question about his recent claim that the financial crisis was a michael fish moment ( a reference to the bbc weatherman who downplayed the uk 's great storm of 1987 . )
q : is economics , in its nature , a michael fish operation ?
haldane says that forecasting is an important part of economics , like weather forecasting .
economists did fail to spot the warning signs ahead of the 2008 crisis , and there was group think ' about issues such as leveraging .
group non-think , mutters committee chairman andrew tyrie haldane says the important thing is to learn from forecasting errors - he mentioned michael fish in 1987 because it has a happy ending .
the same can be true of economics , haldane insists .
we can hope and aspire to do better , because we have learned lessons [ from 2008 ] .
have improvement been made , yes ?
are our forecasting methods better , yes ?
is there room for further improvement , yes , he concludes .
scott bowman of capital economics thinks the uk is on track to borrow significantly less than the current forecast of â£ 68bn this year .

having read january 's public finances , he says : looking through some of the monthly volatility , receipts growth has been fairly steady since june adding to the evidence that the economy has held up well following the vote to leave the eu

documents.title: uk posts biggest january surplus since 2000
text: breaking !
britain has racked up its biggest surplus for a january in 17 years .
the office for national statistics reports that the government achieved a surplus of â£ 9.4bn last month , the best since 2000 , thanks to strong tax receipts .

fraser munro ( @ frasermunropsf ) public sector net # borrowing ( psnb ex ) was â£ 9.4bn in surplus in jan 17 , biggest jan surplus since 2000 [ confusingly , the ons have also changed their methodology for handling corporation tax so it is recorded when the activity took place .
so that forecast of a â£ 14bn surplus is no longer relevant ] .
so with two months to go , it appears that britain will hit its deficit target this financial year .
duncan weldon ( @ duncanweldon ) welcome news for the chancellor as borrowing on course to undershoot the obr forecast .
the big is that britain now owes â£ 1,589.2bn , or around 80.5 % of gross domestic product .

the treasury is taking a cautious approach , with a spokesperson saying : we remain committed to returning the public finances to balance and building on our progress in reducing the deficit from 10 % to 4 % of gdp over the last six years .
next month the chancellor will deliver his spring budget based on updated forecasts from the obr .

documents.title: french bonds hit by le pen worries
text: french government bonds are coming under renewed selling presure , as fears that far right politician marine le pen could become the country 's next president .

despite today 's strong economic data , traders are piling out of french debt and into german bonds instead - fearing a political earthquake when the french head to the polls in late april and early may .

this has driven the gap between french and german 10-year borrowing costs to a new four-year high : holger zschaepitz ( @ schuldensuehner ) oops : # france 10y risk spread over # germany jumps to almost 80bps , highest since 2012 as le pen worries rise .
investors are waking up to the possibility that le pen is on track to win the first round of voting , and could even triumph in the second-round playoff .
opinion polling last weekend put the front national leader on 26 % support , followed b right-winger francois fillon and centrist emmanuel macron on 20 % each .
for a while , people had felt confident that moderate voters would rally around her opponent , whether that was macron or fillon .
but jitters are setting in , with recent surveys showing le pen gaining ground against both men .
emily mansfield of the economist intelligence unit is confident that le pen will not win in the second round .

but if there is a shock result , it could make britain 's brexit negotiations even tougher : if she did come to power , suddenly the focus in brussels would shift away from the uk to making sure that that there was no further ruptures , mansfield told city am .
le pen would encourage the other european countries to close ranks and be even tougher on both france and the uk .
emily mansfield ( @ erm3114 ) i 'm quoted in city am 's latest coverage of the french elections : via @ twitterid
the upshot of today 's pmi reports is that the eurozone economy is up speed this month .

markit says : job creation was the best seen for nine and a half years , order book growth up and business optimism moved higher , all boding well for the recovery to maintain strong momentum in coming months .
inflationary pressures meanwhile continued to intensify .
full details here .
pepijn bergsen ( @ pbergsen ) euro zone pmi clearly did n't get the eurocrisis is back due to greece/le pen memo .
composite at 56 ( 54.4 in jan ) , 70-month high
boom !

company growth across the euro area has hit its fastest rate in almost six years , thanks to the in france ( details ) and germany ( details ) frederik ducrozet ( @ fwred ) euro area composite pmi at a 6 year high , job creation at a 9 1/2 years high .
david reid ( @ cnbcdavy ) euro zone flash composite pmi for february is 56.0 , best since april 2011 .

here 's kit juckes of french bank sociã©tã© gã©nã©rale on today 's eurozone growth figures : france 's composite flash pmi came in at 56.2 this month - and germany 's came in at 56.1 - providing further evidence of the european growth acceleration that will give the euro wings when or if it can get free of its political shackles
greek bonds are strengthening this morning , following last night 's agreement to talk about additional economic reforms in return for bailout cash .
the yield on greece 's two-year debt has dropped to 8.8 % , down from over 9.3 % yesterday .
that means it is seen as less risky , but still quite risky .

documents.title: german growth hits three-year high
text: more encouraging news !
germany 's private sector is enjoying its best month in almost three years .
german manufacturing growth rose to a 37-month high this month , says markit , while service sector growth hit a 3-month high .
and that 's driven the flash germany pmi composite output index up to its highest since april 2014 at 56.1 , up from 54.8 in january .
anything over 50 shows growth .
firms a rise in new business , with manufacturing new order growth hitting a 37-month high , and new export orders rising at the fastest rate since january 2014 .

german pmi trevor balchin , senior economist at ihs markit says : the flash pmi results for february signalled the strongest growth of the german economy for just under three years , with manufacturing in particular expanding at a marked pace and services recovering the momentum lost at the start of the year .
moreover , the new future output index is signalling strong confidence among firms , reaching a new high since its inception in mid-2012 .
economist are applauding the news that french companies have reported such solid growth this month .

capital economics are predicting that the wider economy is up pace : capital economics ( @ capeconeurope ) after jumping to a 69-month high in february , the french composite pmi seems consistent with a sharp rise in french quarterly gdp growth bloomberg 's maxime sbaihi is also impressed : maxime sbaihi ( @ mxsba ) sky is the limit for french # pmi .
`` magnifique '' february survey , with both headline & details looking good .
my take : howard archer of ihs global insight says french companies are n't being distracted by the race to the ãlysã©e palace .
howard archer ( @ howardarcheruk ) pmi shows # french # manufacturing & # services output at 69-month high in feb suggests economy is currently brushing off political uncertainty

documents.title: french private sector growth smashes forecasts
text: breaking : france 's companies are growing at their fastest rate in over five years , despite the uncertainty created by this spring 's presidential elections .
the flash france composite output index , compiled by data firm markit , has surged to 56.2 this month , up from january 's reading of 54.1 .
that 's the highest reading since may 2011 .
service sector companies led the way with strong growth , while manufacturing firms also expanded .
firms across the economy reported solid growth this month , with new business up , meaning they hired more staff for the fourth month running .

it 's an encouraging sign that the eurozone 's second-largest economy has made a decent start to 2017 alex gill of ihs markit , explains : the latest pmi data highlighted a further marked improvement in private sector conditions in france .
output continued to rise in both monitored sectors .
service providers remained the driver of overall growth , as evidenced by further sharp expansions in new orders and employment , the sharpest in five- and-a-half years in each case .
the was also positive for manufacturers , albeit slightly less rosy .
rates of increase in client demand and staffing numbers eased from january as the sector continues to be weighed down by marked cost pressures .
reaction to follow !

documents.title: the agenda : greek bailout latest , uk public finances , mark carney
text: good morning , and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy , the financial markets , the eurozone and business .
today we 'll be watching greece , following yesterday 's agreement to allow debt inspectors to return to athens .
once there they 'll be discussing a new round of tax , pensions and labour market reform , to possibly pave the way for greece to receive more bailout loans ( to repay its creditors with ) .
amanda cooper ( @ a coops1 ) ecb imf esm & ec to visit # greece after deal on new reforms for aid .
we ca n't call them `` troika '' any other ideas ?
as we covered in last night 's liveblog , eurozone officials are talking up the idea that the focus is moving from austerity to reforms ( after almost seven years of pain ) .
the greece government has been defending the agreement , saying that it 's fiscally neutral ' ( so any savings can be ploughed into tax cuts ) .
but the opposition new democracy party is n't impressed , declaring that the government is celebrating the return of the institutions to greece while the economy is sinking .

greece standoff over ¬86bn bailout eases after brussels deal read more also coming up today data firm markit are releasing new flash ' economic surveys , showing how private sector companies in germany , france and the wider eurozone are faring this month .
8am : french manufacturing and services pmi 8.30am : german manufacturing and services pmi 9am : eurozone manufacturing and services pmi at 9.30am , we get the latest uk public finances for january .
they 're likely to show a surplus of over â£ 14bn , thanks to a flurry of self-assessment tax payments .
then at 10am , bank of england governor mark carney and colleagues will climb into the ring for another bout with mps on parliament 's treasury committee .
they 'll be discussing the latest inflation report , and the bank 's new forecasts for higher growth and inflation .
brexit will doubtless come up ( again ) .
and in the city , the big news overnight is that banking giant hsbc has posted a 62 % slide in profits .

my colleague jill treanor has been up extra-early to cover it ; here 's her story : hsbc cuts pay of senior executives after failing to combat potential financial crime read more mining giants bhp billiton and anglo american , hotels group intercontinental , and plumbing and building materials firm wolseley are also reporting results .
